bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, May 6, 1940

div1.p: Hench gives brief details of his trip to Cuba and discusses the controversy over the proper location of the site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, May 6, 1940
div1.p:
I have been so busy since my return that I haven't had a chance to write
you. I found a lot of work waiting for me, and a medical convention, during which
we had house guests. Then Kahler developed an acute appendix and was operated upon
about two weeks ago, but is doing splendidly and is back home.

I should like to spend an evening telling you of the interesting experiences
I had in Havana, tracing down the yellow fever story. I went down there expecting
to investigate the story for two days, and to loaf for eight days. I thought I would
see Moran for a few hours, visit the site of the Camp Lazear and that was all. In-
stead, I got involved in quite a controversy. I soon found out that the camp site
that has been marked by the government and where they plan to have a memorial building,
which has been named Camp Lazear, is not the proper camp site at all. After consider-
able work I located it a mile away. Then, I had to try to prove it, and I had several
conferences with the Secretary of War and the Secretary of Health, with their respective
staffs, as well as the officials of the Finlay Institute. I had to get documentary
proof and also collected a certain amount of photographs taken by myself, others in
the form of professional photographs, some of which I plan to offer in larger form
for framing in the Lazear Memorial Building, should you care to have me do so. Suffice
it to say I think I finally convinced the government officials that I was right and
they have asked me to write the matter up, forward it to the Cuban government, and
they will appoint a commission to determine the final site. There is a long story
behind this that I can't bother you about now. I never worked so hard in my life,
but I had a very interesting time.

I expect to see General Kean in Washington. He was Surgeon-General shortly
after the experiments, and was directly connected with the work in Havana in 1900.
When I get time, I will write this all up for you in a preliminary fashion and will
of course also send the complete copy with documentary evidence to the United States
Army Medical Museum.
I regret indeed that you cannot give me moral support at Lafayette, June 7.
div1.closer: Hastily yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
